Utterance: <sigh> hi
Hi, welcome back! It’s good to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
I've been okay, mostly just busy with school.
That’s understandable. You mentioned last time that you were feeling a bit overwhelmed. Have those feelings changed at all?
Um, I think they’ve been a little better, but I still feel some pressure.
That’s good to hear there’s been some improvement. Can you tell me what’s been helping you feel a bit better?
I’ve been trying to take more walks and listen to music when I feel stressed.
Those are great coping strategies! Have you noticed any specific situations or tasks that trigger those feelings of pressure?
Yeah, sometimes it’s just the amount of work I have. I feel like I’m juggling too much.
It sounds like you’re managing a lot. Have you considered breaking down your tasks into smaller, more manageable pieces?
I’ve tried that a bit, but it’s hard to stay motivated sometimes.
Motivation can be tricky. What do you think would help boost your motivation?
Maybe setting smaller goals or rewards for myself would help.
That sounds like a solid plan. What kind of rewards do you think would motivate you?
Maybe treating myself to a nice meal or a new book after I finish a project.
Those sound like nice rewards! Let’s set a goal for the next week. How about picking one task to break down and reward yourself after completing it?
Okay, I can do that. I have a project due next week that I can work on.
Perfect! What’s the first step you can take towards that project?
I think I can start by outlining what I need to do.
Great idea! How does that feel to you?
It feels manageable, I think.
That’s wonderful to hear. Now, you mentioned feeling down at times. Have you noticed any patterns with those feelings?
Sometimes it happens when I feel like I’m not making progress.
That makes sense. It’s common to feel down when we perceive a lack of progress. What do you think you can do when those feelings arise?
I guess I could remind myself of what I’ve accomplished so far.
Yes! Reflecting on your achievements can be very helpful. Is there a specific achievement you’re proud of that you can think of?
I completed a tough math course last semester, and I did well.
That’s an excellent achievement! Celebrating those successes can help shift your mindset. Would you like to incorporate that into your next week’s goals?
Sure, I can write it down and remind myself of it.
That sounds like a great idea. How do you feel about sharing that with someone close to you?
I think I could tell my mentor about it.
That’s a wonderful choice! Sharing our successes with others can reinforce those positive feelings. Have you spoken to your mentor recently?
Not in the last week. I should reach out.
That could be a great way to reconnect. What would you like to discuss with them?
I’d like to talk about my goals and maybe get some advice on managing my workload.
That’s a productive conversation to have. How do you think they would respond?
They’re usually really supportive and give good advice.
That’s fantastic. It sounds like you have a strong support system. How do you feel about leaning on that support when you’re feeling overwhelmed?
I think I should do that more often. I tend to keep things to myself.
It’s understandable to want to handle things alone, but reaching out can be very beneficial. What’s one thing you can do this week to reach out more?
I can send them a message and see if they’re free to chat.
Excellent! That’s a proactive step. Let’s check in on that next time. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
No, I think we covered a lot. Thank you.
You’re very welcome! I’m looking forward to hearing how your week goes. Remember to take things one step at a time. Goodbye for now!
Goodbye!
